commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Stand next to a club?  (3)
2. Put a pilot back into action  (5)
3. To pieces?  (4)
4. It's a straight shot  (4)(5)
5. One taking the words right out of your mouth?  (3)(6)


TEE
REAIR
ODES
NEAT VODKA
LIP READER

"I know I've seen these plates and bowls before. I just don't know ware."

("I can almost pitcher it.")
Way too many names for a monday (or any day)

Enjoyable puzzle. Felt like there were a few more naticks for a Monday than I expect. I knew OTIS Redding but not PETULA Clark. nor Paco and I prefer college basketball to pro So I had to stretch for Malone. As an English teacher I appreciate the word play around Still on the Table
Way too many proper nouns, especially for a Monday. Not a fan
The rare ‚Äúthis was a little tough for a Monday, no?‚Äù  Mostly enjoyable, but definitely a lot of proper nouns.

Sam writes:
"I doubted my interpretation of 58-Across as too much of a stretch, until a puzzle editor affirmed it ‚Äî and that‚Äôs also what made it so satisfying to uncover. It felt like a triumph of my own imagination."

Sam,
Perhaps you shouldn't doubt your theme interpretations; it seemed rather obvious to me. To put it another way, what else could it mean?

I had two different crosses that I didn‚Äôt know and had to run the alphabet until they looked right to me. VAI_/_SSA as well as LOC_E/A_ERS. I tried out each vowel the 27D/41A intersection and ran the alphabet to get LOCKE/AKERS and the gold star üòÖüòÆ‚Äçüí® I am only one more day away from achieving a 4 year streak of completing these puzzles without assistance. Thank you to Daniel for a clever theme and slightly harder than usual for me Monday!
This one caught me off guard! Mondays are typically just a  ‚Äúhow fast can I do it‚Äù day, but wasnt setting any PBs with this one, lol
This was a lovely puzzle. I enjoyed it greatly. Thanks!
10D and 22A was a stretch for a Monday to cross two proper names. I did not know either of these people.
Ah, Petula Clark. The unattainable ideal for a 13-year-old me. I still watch this from time to time, daydreaming... https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YWTun8B1lHg
This felt more like a Tuesday‚Ä¶sorry to folks new to crosswords!

This is a Wednesday in disguise. Over 7 minute solve, and I count at least two Naticks. I was able to correct them, but it was only by guessing. I had LOChE misspelled crossing with AhERS. I knew Locke could only be spelled LOCHE or LOCKE, but Michelle Ahers and Akers were equally plausible. The other is VAIA/ASSA. I had VAIo/oSSA. Knew it had to be vowel, and O was my second guess. But those aside, I was already at 7 minutes before I started looking for mistakes
I object to calling an a.m. radio a stereo‚Ä¶ a.m. is generally broadcast in mono.
Good. Though seemed like a bit too many proper names for a Monday.

I started across, encountering Broadway, baseball, and assorted names and trivia in the first few lines of the puzzle. By the time I ended this pass, the grid looked like I was doing a late week puzzle - there were so many blank squares everywhere! The down pass helped, but I still wasn't finished. Several more passes were needed.

The solve took Tuesday time, in the end, and I was able to deal with it without outside help only due to previous NYT puzzle experience: BOFFO I remembered today, somehow, even though it looks like gibberish to me, and it confused me greatly when I first encountered it here, earlier this year I think.

This was my least favorite kind of puzzle: made hard for me not my witty clues but inclusion of proper names.

PACO de Lucia was one of my few gimmes today. I really like his rendition of Joaquin Rodrigo's Concierto de Aranjuez.

Also, if you have VANITY PLATES, I will judge you by them.
An elegant and satisfying puzzle. Thank you!
Just noting that Ask Me Another (23 Across) was cancelled in 2021.

I knew LOCKE because of this:

I went to a very mundane, low-level undergraduate school.  I had no bread, and my local university was giving me an essentially free ride.

But I got into a fairly prestigious grad school, but I had almost no experience with the kind of people who go to prestigious schools.

I knew I was in a different world when I was in one of the bathrooms there, and there was an arrow pointing to the lock on the door, and the graffiti "John Locke".

We're not in Colorado anymore.
Had Rawls before LOCKE.  A little knowledge is a dangerous thing.

Not a good Monday (or any day of the week). Awkward crossings, too many names, some esoteric answers, and an ugly looking grid. I was turned off from 1A (BOFFO? Really??) and it didn‚Äôt get much better from there. Honestly surprised it made it through.

Ok, for all of those of you who only see the gloom and doom side of me--I have a story that is coming close to warming the cockles of my heart.  Whatever those are.

I looked out the window onto my back yard a couple of weeks ago, and I saw a deer.  That's not really that unusual, but this deer was in the process of delivering a fawn.

So I got to see the little guy's first attempts at walking, his first feeding.  

Since then, the mother and her fawn have come back to the yard several times.  The mother munches on our hostas, and the little one runs back and forth in the yard, sometimes kicking up his back paws.

In my more pensive moments, I like to think of this as a metaphor the universe is playing out to try to cheer me up.  Renewed birth.  Rising up from the ugliness.  That kind of thing.

I don't know if it'll work or not, but it does make me feel there's hope, somehow.

The mention of Copland is so American and nostalgic! His Fanfare for the Common Man is played by everyone and was even covered by ELP back around ‚Äò75, or so. Thanks to Daniel Raymon for the memory. ELP also did Tocatto, and unrelated, Mussorgsky‚Äôs Pictures at an Exhibition, but I digress

There's just something about the word Ether that fascinates me. Not in the chemical  sense, more in the literary and metaphysical sense. The theory of a substance that ‚Äúpermeates all space, including the interstices between the particles of ordinary matter.‚Äù Or the ‚Äúrefined element supposed to be breathed in heaven or by the gods.‚Äù It just seems to transcend the human imagination. I can't explain why, I just like it.

I love that Locke and ether are side by side, by the way. I had done a study in college on John Locke‚Äôs modern idea of tabula rasa. Makes for very interesting and some often-heated discussion, as it's believed to be pure conjecture. It's best to read up on it, since much of it is based on opinion. I could do the theory no justice in this forum. 
Trivia: the ‚ÄúLocke‚Äù character on ‚ÄúLost‚Äù was named after him. Mr. Eco was named after Umberto Eco.

IOBJECT to AM being stereo. From the early days of amplitude modulated radio characteristics, stereo is just not possible. Frequency modulation has the design and characteristics to broadcast in true stereo. Both travel through my favorite ‚Äúether,‚Äù with FM being to a lesser distance and strength. But, I suppose I'll get over it.
Oh! I had the same Natick. Ossa and Vaio were not coming to mind for me. Thank you for the help.
I liked this puzzle.  I did have to look up a couple of things.  But I am old enough to remember Petula Clarke.

Harder than most Mondays for me but I liked some of the entries I found trickier (PETULA and BOFFO and AKERS come to mind).

Thanks for a fun start to the week!
Strands Monday theme is super tacky given recent events. Do better.

As one of the two puzzles I still do without Autocheck each week, I thought this went pretty nicely, for this oldster. Well, no, 26:44 isn't really "nice," but some of that time was spent trying to find the error I had made. 

The first time I got back to 39A I figured OXIDeNT was probably wrong, so I changed it to OXIDANT. But no reward, so I changed  it back and resumed error hunting.

No luck, so I looked up "oxident" and got corrected. I fixed it again and this time they told me I had solved the puzzle. I guess it was just my laptop, which very frequently reacts to typing or mouse clicking with a distinct delay.
Wasn't expecting so many proper names and naticks on a Monday

Lock(e) two days in a row! What sort of sorcery is this!? 

Reminds me of earlier today. Got to go in the sea today and ran into some folks my husband knew long ago. It was lovely. We talked a bit about how it's nice to be here this time of year because of all the fruit coming in. The man asked if I like mango. I told him it's my favorite. He asked me if I'd ever eaten it in the sea. The sea!? Why, no... who has ever heard of eating mango in the sea!? Then, as if some magical mango man, he conjured up a mango out of the ETHER, or perhaps his pocket, and handed it to me. It was like a miracle on ice, only not. My husband laughed and told me they always used to eat mangoes in the sea. So today, for the first time, I ate a mango in the sea.  What a world! It was extra delicious and a wee bit salty! Okay, ILLSTOP!

I enjoyed the puzzle!!  No OBJECTions. I started with  STILLONTHEfence but the kindly crosses quickly disabused me of the fence and led me to the table. The rest came smoothly!  I guess there were a lot of names, but today they were in my wheelhouse. Even AARON, which surprised me. I put it in right away but was prepared to remove it.

TAGSALE filled itself in but I hadn't heard of it before. I assume it's the same as what I'd call a rummage, yard, or garage sale. 

Anyhow, my mother-in-law is having a bad night hallucination wise, it's going to be a long one for us. Thankful for puzzles to keep me going in the spaces between episodes. So hard to see her like this.

The only clue that really stumped me was the event in a garage or front yard. I got there by other means, but I'd never heard of it.

I appreciated that the sports clue could be arrived at by indirect means, because being in Europe, they always stump me.

Nice puzzle, just happened to feel like doing it on the phone instead of the computer, so a little slower than usual. No problems with the fill. 

Thanks, Daniel.

From Daniel‚Äôs Constructor‚Äôs Notes: ICE(d) WATER clued as ‚Äòstarting pitcher‚Äô would be fantastic for a later-in-the-week puzzle, ditto for ‚Äòuneaten‚Äô for STILL ON THE TABLE. 

Quick and fun today. A shoutout to Utah Jazz and Karl Malone‚Äôs ubiquitous Hardee‚Äôs and Larry H. Miller Toyota commercials, the backdrop of my tender years. And to John Stockton, of course. I haven‚Äôt cared about basketball since those two stopped playing it together. 

PACO de Lucia is sublime. If my husband is not in a jazz mood, there‚Äôs a 50% chance PACO comes on when he starts his car. The other 50% is Ottmar Liebert. It‚Äôs the kind of guitar music my parents had hoped I‚Äôd play when they got me a guitar and lessons when I was six. 40 years later, I remember exactly one piece and, believe you me, it‚Äôs not flamenco. Kind of ironic I ended up marrying a flamenco nut. DIOS mio, does Spanish music feed the soul or what. (I should‚Äôve listened to my parents.)

Happy Monday, everyone. The grindstone awaits.
Very difficult Monday puzzle! Still working on the puzzle and I‚Äôm already double my average time

Great start to the new puzzle week! It's clever, flows nicely, and I only needed to look at a few down clues; I probably could have solved just on the across, but glancing at down allowed me to finish with no hiccups.

I would not say that Evian, expensive mineral water from the Alps, is a competitor of Aquafina, filtered tap water! Perhaps Dasani would be a better comparison! (This is neither complaint nor criticism; it's merely an observation.)

Any puzzle with Tori AMOS and OTIS Redding is okay by me. 
Thanks Daniel.
First time doing a Monday. I didn‚Äôt know they had themed answers like this one. Lots of fun.

Years ago I had a Sony Vaio laptop, so I was confused when the crosses gave me VAIO. I knew it as a model that Sony issued. I had no idea that it had become a company independent of Sony, which I learned by looking it up after I completed the puzzle.

@Sam, loved your cattle-call photo-pun to go with ‚ÄúLowest Voice‚Äù ‚Äì ruminating on that will have me smiling all day.  




Et tu, emu.
Poignant to see VANITY PLATE. The vanity of all  mortal pursuits is a common theme of still life painting in the early modern period.
Monday?
Satisfyingly challenging for a Monday! Good one.

Nice Monday puzzle and a good workout. Other than 17a, I needed some crosses for all of the theme answers but they came pretty smoothly. And... the reveal was just about the last thing I filled in. That's always a nice touch. Unusual puzzle find today, but quite clever. A Tuesday from September 8, 2015 by Jacob Stulberg. Some of the 'theme' answers, though they were not identified as such: SWAMPGAS MPG PGA STOPGAP KEEPGOING APGARP PINUPGIRL LIPGLOSS And there were 5 others. And then the 'reveal': "Somewhat family-friendly ... or a title for this puzzle, as suggested by the completed grid?" PGTHIRTEEN Thought that was pretty clever. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=9/8/2015&g=60&d=A ...
The Tuesday-est (perhaps Wednesday-est, all things considered) Monday puzzle ever. Did not enjoy.
Years ago, I was drinking a bottle of EVIAN when it occurred to me that it was 'naive' spelled backwards.  Haven't bought one since then.  ILLSTOP now.

I‚Äôm surprised by how many found this harder than the average Monday. After a mistake on my first entry (SMASH instead of BOFFO), I sailed through it. Unfamiliar proper nouns were eased by the crosses. I guess I‚Äôm on the constructor‚Äôs wavelength today, or maybe we‚Äôre of a similar vintage.

So, I tried imagining a still life painting that included objects from the puzzle, and mine had a MASK in a bowl, a small SLAT on a plate, and SOBA in a pitcher.  

While solving, I tried guessing the revealer after uncovering the theme answers, and I actually thought it could have something to do with a still life painting. I got no farther than that, but felt mighty good anyway, I, who usually do so badly at this game.  

By triggering my imagination and riddle-cracking muscles, this puzzle got my thumbs enthusiastically pointing up.

The puzzle has pop, with three NYT answer debuts and five once-befores ‚Äì answers including I‚ÄôLL STOP, STILL ON THE TABLE, EAT LOCAL, I OBJECT, STARTING PITCHER, and VANITY PLATE.  

I liked EVIAN crossing WATER.  I loved the theme because of its subtlety.

Daniel, you are just a Saturday away from hitting the cycle.  Go for it!  And thank you for a splendid outing today.
Daniel should have stayed away, this was dreadful for a Monday

Cute theme---miscellaneous four-letter words that start with O: OTIS, OTRO, OSSA, OATH, OMNI, OHSO. Not quite a word ladder.

The actual theme was ... well, let's say, a bit SHY of BOFFO.

OK, not a fan of this puzzle. An awful lot of names here, in both senses of "awful lot". Surprised to have crossings like OSSA/VAIO and AKERS/TATE in a Monday puzzle.

Finished after looking up a good lot of obscure people and US sport stuff, a bit of a slog to be honest.

Only 3 themed entries, and only using the second word of each - I often check the Wordplay column and notice that I missed something amazingly clever in the theme, but this time no. Contrary to the constructor's notes the theme wasn't clever (although I agree it wasn't complex either) and the fill wasn't straightforward.

My advice to the editors would have been: get rid of the theme, swap a load of the names for less frustrating fill, and turn it into a Friday puzzle.
Far too many name crossings for a Monday. Am I the only one that had PALINDROMES instead of VANITY PLATE? I think my Monday brain needs more coffee‚Ä¶

Laughed at your photo illustration pick, Sam! Low humor.

I admit, I didn't think on it long enough to pick up on the allusion to still life art. For a Monday, dinnerware on the table seemed enough of a theme.
And a throwback reference to British/US differences in tabling a motion.

A modern cell phone might be rather boring in a still life, it's just a rectangular box. You'd need to have some round and organic things in the tableau to give it contrast and life. What else might we find on a modern table --- a pizza box or Mickey D's fries? Maybe your car keys and sunglasses. I did a still life with binoculars once, but it still had a vase and fruit.

It struck me that this puzzle had a lot of teachable moments, lessons in NYT cluing conventions. For instance, 38D , "Cousin of an alligator, informally", would later in the week be clued as "Cousin of a gator" letting "gator" hint that the answer is the shortened and informal CROC.
And 61D, "N.Y.C.'s Madison ___" tells you that the answer is abbreviated to AVE because N.Y.C. is a short form.

Dunno why I'm so talky this morning, I'LL STOP.

BOFFO puzzle, Daniel.
Frustrating Monday puzzle. Geez. Also there is no such thing as AM STEREO. FM is in stereo AM is mono. AM is just RADIO.

@Sam Corbin

Still life with a cat?  I suppose so, but would the cat agree to be "still"?  (Perhaps, if it were napping.)

Still life with a cow?  Certainly not, if it's one of those famous jumping cows.  (They're notoriously difficult to tip.)

Do they low when they jump?
Moo!

Hmm...looks like someone is late getting to the milking!...'cause  those cows are *desperate* for relief.  

Oh, the puzzle.  
Well, it's Monday.  

I graduated from HS in 1965; "Crazy Downtown" (a take-off on PETULA's hit) was all the rage.  Heard it on the radio riding home with another student from our last band concert as graduating seniors.  (I had a huge crush on the guy...sigh! He was oblivious.)
Solved it right at my Monday average, so it seems like a Monday puzzle to me!  There is also NBA coach Michael MALONE, who won a championship in 2023.
WORD NERDS TO RAYMON, BOFFO!

I‚Äôm very surprised by all the complaints about names. Yes, there were quite a few (9, by my count) for a Monday, but most were far from obscure. And all were easily filled with the crosses. Only two names crossed: AKERS and LOCKE. I am not familiar with AKERS,  but I think anyone who doesn‚Äôt know LOCKE should blame their high school history teacher, not the puzzle.

I also think there‚Äôs no excuse not to know AARON Copeland or OTIS Redding. And even this sportsball-ignorant solver who‚Äôs never watched an entire game of basketball knew Karl MALONE.

Names, yes. But they were Monday-level names. With Monday-level crosses.

In Junior High, everyone's favorite teacher, our English teacher, rewrote the lyrics of Downtown, instead singing about Noun Town.

She would even occasionally put Downtown on the jukebox at lunch and walk through the cafeteria loudly singing her version. Love it!!

I think about this a weird amount of time for so many years later, and certainly anytime I hear the real song. Loved her commitment to the gig and to her students. She was an unforgettable hoot!
welp he can go back on hiatus. it didn‚Äôt feel like a monday puzzle at all. very obscure. not fun.

I know it wasn't so for others, but very Monday for me.
My first clue was putting in the word PITCHER. The first part of that answer came a little later.

Next clue was when I filled in COLLEGEBOWL, which, as kids, my brother, sister, and I watched religiously. I know my brother could have beaten every one of those panelists, every time. 

Then I got the revealer, and the theme fell into place. I had no problems except for not knowing the name of the computer, but finally got that.  Quick, Monday, and fun. I enjoyed this start to my week. 

Go ahead and grumble, those of you who must. You love to blame the creator and the editors for your own lack of knowledge and refusal to look things up. But you know that you can't hit 100% with every puzzle; there's always the gallery of disgruntled next to the gruntles. (No, it's not a word; don't bother looking it up. I already did.)
Surely I‚Äôm not the only reader who thinks the NYT should have held its Monday Strands until a day when the top story isn‚Äôt about 20-some children dying at a summer camp. That was poorly done.

Another frustrating Monday with, in my opinion, far too many specific people names needed to be known.  Least fun aspect of NYT crosswords is when they introduce too many.  I dont mind a couple since you can easily context clue them but this one had 6 or 7 very specific names in pretty key spots.  Doesn't quite feel as fair
A surprisingly tough Monday. normally I finish in about 5 minutes, this one took me 13. Feels more like a Tuesday.

I didn't find it that much harder than a normal Monday overall although some of the answers seemed a bit awkward.  The only clue that really gave me trouble is BOFFO, I have never heard that term before.

Yes, some of the proper names were in way too specialized a niche for a Monday, but in most of those cases the crossing clues gave them clear shape.

This seemed like a normal Monday to me even with a couple of unknown names, but I thought the revealer was phenomenal!

The first picture in today's column isn't particularly mooving(okay, I'll cud it out), but the second photo?

Is that their first time at a museum? Are they unfamiliar with the concept of paintings? Color me confused.
Lots of proper nouns and awkward answers made this a puzzle full of naticks. Generally unpleasant experience and a poor start to the week.

I have to ask: The picture with today's column -- I did not know you could have cows living so close to a marshmallow farm. 

It seems the sanitary issues would be complicated.

I don't get the complaints for this one, it felt super Monday to me. Finished under 4 minutes, below Mon average for me, maybe it just happened to hit specialty knowledge I'm lucky to have? I did find it weird to include Ask Me Another, a mid-tier radio show/podcast that's been off the air for four years, but I listened to the whole run of it so it wasn't a problem for me in this puzzle.

I think this puzzle may be easier for older solvers, but for those of us born after 2000, it was definitely tricky. I would say the number of proper nouns push it past  Monday difficulty, and, overall found it frustrating.
Was this crossword designed to get as many proper nouns as possible? Very unenjoyable Monday
Am stereo is not a "band". Am radio possibly works but this is just a bad clue.

Quite crunchy for a Monday. Glad to see I‚Äôm in good company and it‚Äôs not just me.
No complaints though. Love the theme, plus we got the TATE in there. Not the Modern though; I‚Äôm not a fan. Too Brutalist and ultra modern for my pedestrian taste. Give me the National any day.
Needed the crosses for all names except LOCKE and the sublime OTIS. Had my usual blank space for the sporting names/positions. Ditto tv channels, actor and quiz show. Didn‚Äôt slow me up too badly though.

My heartfelt sympathies to all suffering with the situation in Texas. Puts my grumbling about a lack of rain here into perspective.

I didn‚Äôt find this too bad. 22 minutes is quite fast for me. I‚Äôve only ever done one Monday without look-ups so I expect to look up some. 

Didn‚Äôt know MALONE or the AM clue. Despite what many claim - that you can‚Äôt possible not know the mega stars of ball sports - no, I don‚Äôt! 

When I saw the comments recently about Strands I thought I‚Äôd missed something dreadful - today - on the news, linked to the Prescriptions theme. I read comments from the earliest , I didn‚Äôt see the first Strands. Glad it was fixed.
I will STILL AT THE TABLE trying to figure out why I hadn't solved it yet because without looking at the down clues, both ADE and TIX worked.   Good one!
I'm normally a good speller, but OXIDeNT forced me to flyspeck (and I'm terrible with music, so didn't know PACO de Luc√≠a).
Interesting that the top two comments and both of their confirming replies were from Australia, Poland, London, and Canada.

23 proper nouns... when you are working the downs beginning at 10D, of the next 15 clues,  9 of them are proper nouns.
then, crossing LOCKE / FRESE / AKERS.
one of the laziest nytxws i've seen published.
Did anyone else think the clue for 18D should have omitted the word "similar" (i.e., 'Response to "You're too kind"')?

Wow, stumped by a Monday puzzle, I think that's a first for me. Like in the column, I ended with VAI* and *SSA, but I made an incorrect answer first and had to guess again. I don't remember that computer brand coming up before, and it's been long enough that the mountain didn't come up mind. Oh well, an interesting way to start the week!

Live! From the table, it‚Äôs still Saturday-level complaints!
Starring all your favourite Not Ready For Prime-Time-Monday Players (each one with a proper noun for a name).

I liked this puzzle. Fresh is better than a rerun.
I thought 58 across could have been clues as "an artful description of 40 down.".... When I go to a restaurant they often ask me if I'd like sparkling or "still"

The pianist Glenn Gould is most closely associated with the music of J. S. Bach, when he isn't with Schoenberg or Hindemith; but he had a curious fondness for a certain British pop star of the 1960's. (and truck stops): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j5Y4wVWz-AQ (as portrayed by the Canadian actor Colm Feore.)

The most Friday-ish Monday ever.  Not a fan. Puzzles that are heavily dependent on proper nouns (particularly obscure proper nouns), for me, end up feeling quite cheap. Glad that the older crowd enjoyed it, though.
The amount of proper nouns here almost RUINed my streak

Surprised to see so many complaints about this puzzle. I found it fairly average in terms of difficulty for a Monday. Maybe *slightly* tougher is all. I got the proper names I wasn't familiar with through crossings, with the exception of the Natick at 27D/41A.

I liked this puzzle.  Nice Monday challenge.  I hope the constructor doesn‚Äôt feel bad about OSSA; for individual mountains in crosswords, there are OSSA and Ida in Greece, and Etna in Sicily.  The Oreos of mountains, and fair, or good to learn in a Monday puzzle, in my opinion.

Lovely Monday puzzle with a bit of crunch. I didn‚Äôt know the Flamenco guitarist, the soccer star, the computer brand, or the basketball player‚Äîbut got them all with help from crosses. I‚Äôm sure you won‚Äôt let the complaints in the comments bother you too much. So many of us enjoyed it and appreciated a Monday puzzle that didn‚Äôt just whizz by.
For 45A I immediately thought of IT'S ACADEMIC, but I don't know if it's well known outside D.C./Baltimore.
Not sure why so many disliked the puzzle. I found it a usual Monday. I mean, c‚Äômon, it even had ‚Äúeely‚Äù!
Pretty good puzzle, I like a grid I don‚Äôt immediately blaze through. On my first pass i had SONY instead of VAIO - I believe at one point, they were the same company!

A couple of late answer history searches - mostly inspired by the reactions of many solvers to today's puzzle. 

First: 

MONDAYMONDAY 

Nope - never been in a puzzle but at least it is in the Xword Info word lists. 

and then...

CANTTRUSTTHATDAY

Nope - and even CANTTRUST and THATDAY have never even been a part of any answer in a puzzle. 

I'm done. 

....
RIP to Ask Me Another. The question/puzzle writing on that show was so clever. I was a contestant on the show's Washington DC special episode.

I‚Äôm kind of afraid to bring it up but I saw some of the very negative comments about today‚Äôs Strands puzzle and I don‚Äôt understand. One of the posts said something about the NYT having taken down the first one and replaced it with one that wasn‚Äôt offensive. I live in California so did I see a different Strands than some parts of the country did?

And.. as usual my late puzzle find. I'm sure I must have done this one but of course had completely forgotten it. Anyway - a Thursday from May 7, 2020 by Bruce Haight and Peter A. Collins. Three theme answers. Here they are with the clues: "Australian's caution against entering a battlefield?" BUTMATETHERESWAR "Just a reminder: the golf course is reserved for the guys tomorrow," e.g.? MENSDAYWARNING "Would you mind getting that officer out of bed?" CARETOWAKEAMAJOR Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/7/2020&g=36&d=A ...

Hopefully this is the last appearance of AM STEREO unless it's supposed to be ironic. The AM radio band is strictly mono. Only FM stations can be in stereo. A stereo broadcast over AM would require two synchronized channels, and exactly zero news programs would ever bother with something so costly, technically difficult, and utterly esoteric.

I generally dislike names of people, places, and companies or organizations (especially when they are abbreviations/initialisms) in a puzzle. Even when I know them, which can be a solid anchor for a tricky area, I don‚Äôt get the fun out of them that I get out of word-play. 

But because I continue to work my way (slowly) through the archives, today‚Äôs puzzle seemed really not bad at all. In an earlier reply, Xword Junkie suggests 15 or more proper nouns are in today‚Äôs puzzle, and that seems about right. Well, just today I did the puzzle from Tuesday, April 4, 1995, and below is my count (there is some slight subjectivity, but I am confident the total is accurate +/- 2, based on my gut feeling :) 

11 answers are a person‚Äôs name (I‚Äôm giving Cain & Abel a pass, so this could be 12)
  6 answers are place names
  6 answers are other capitalized things, two of which are abbreviations.
  5 clues involve knowing who a person is from their name.
So, that‚Äôs 28 times you need to know a proper noun in that puzzle. And they cross - boy do they cross! For one example: one 5-letter place name has the last three letters crossed with two name answers and a name-in-clue answer that itself is a proper noun I didn‚Äôt count because it‚Äôs a state. Or how about this: two stacked names, one of only four letters in length, three of which are crossed with proper nouns. 

And that was a Tuesday.

One of the worst Monday puzzles ever. Stop catering to the lowest common denominator in society. So many clues that don't make any sense. And we need to keep Spanish terms out of the puzzles. It's not fair to legal Americans.

Megan,

There were some people you did not know, but were there really any Naticks? You stretched for MALONE. Did you fill PETULA and PACO from the crosses? If so, you had no (personal) Naticks.

Megan,

You're an English teacher; 
I hope you appreciate  usage. 

A (personal) natick is not an answer you don't know; it is when two answers you don't know cross, and even filling most of the letters from crosses you can't get the cross of the two words. 

You didn't know PETULA or PACO; did you know the answers that crossed them? If so, you had no naticks (and learned two new answers). 

(Since you are an English teacher. I hope you did know all the answers that crossed them.)

@Al  in Pittsburgh

Actually, it wasn't: I needed crosses. Locke was only mentioned in passing at my high school and university. Polish Law schools fixate unhealthily on Germanic philosophy of law and government: the likes of Hans Kelsen and George Jellinek haunted most of the text books I had to study, and Locke was nowhere to be seen.

Also, the Philosophy of Law course was offered for 5th year students. By that time most of us were working at law firms, and philosophy was the last thing on our minds. The fact the lecturer was a drunk didn't help. One day I arrived at the early-evening lecture in my suit straight from the office, where we dealt with corporate clients and their multi-million business deals. The red-nosed lecturer went on: 

"Lawyers! Sometimes you must tell your client: I won't do what you're asking, because it's against my philosophy!"

I mean, really...

@Andrzej

Thank you for reminding me of Joaquin Rodrigo's Concierto de Aranjuez, one of my all-time favorites, which I haven't listened to in decades. Off to listen now, instead of going to bed.

@Al in Pittsburgh

Regarding John Locke and the 4th:
Did you know that Locke's Second Treatise on Government thought that the foundation of "natural law" centered around the protection of "life, liberty, and...property"?
Jefferson changed "property" to "pursuit of happiness", which sounds like an improvement on Locke's "materialism", but no one really knows what "pursuit of happiness" means, or how a government is supposed to guarantee it.

I'll ignore the inconsistency of guaranteeing an inalienable right to liberty for all people while allowing the institution of slavery to continue.  (That's not Locke's fault.)

@The X-Phile

Isn't the concept of the pursuit of happiness akin to Dworkin's right to equal concern and respect?

@The X-Phile,

There‚Äôs a book that came out last year called ‚ÄúThe Pursuit of Happiness‚Äù by Jeffrey Rosen that explores this very issue.
@Andrzej  -- Your first reply, starting "It's almost as if..." got me laughing out loud.

@Andrzej
My husband had vanity plates for many years -- HITEK JD.  He says the JD stands for Juris Doctor -- law degree.  I claim it stands for Juvenile Delinquent.  
But, he was a patent attorney in Silicon Valley for 42  years, so saw lots of interesting stuff.  He's retired, but spent the last 5 years writing a memoir of his practice -- called HITEK JD!  He had lots of interesting experiences with the movers and shakers of this crazy place.

The Kindle version is out on Amazon, and the print version comes out on Friday.   Amazon self-publish is amazing!  A "real" publisher wants $25K up front and gives you a few hundred copies.  Amazon prints on demand, so no up-front costs.  He doesn't expect it to be a big best-seller, but is a history buff and wanted to record his view of the last 50 years of tech innovation.

@Patrick

I felt that was a particularly non-Monday clue -- and that show was recorded in my neighborhood during its tenure! Very poor editing, IMHO. (Maybe I'd give it a wee bit more credit if somehow it tied into the theme, but just no.)

@Francis

One of the things I like about the Polish system of education is how egalitarian it is. Public schools and universities are generally free. They are also generally better than private ones. Thus, people from all walks of life meet there: rich and poor, from the country and urban centers, etc. I didn't appreciate this as much as I should have as a student, but now that I've been a uni teacher for 20 years, I really enjoy getting to know all those diverse young people, and learning from them about how different us humans may be. Reaching them all is one of the greatest, and most rewarding, challenges of my work.

@Andrzej

It sounds terrific.  I won't point out the failings of the American system, because it causes angst.  And it's quite well known.

I taught for about 15 years, chemistry, at a small but not entirely hopeless university.

I also enjoyed reaching students, while I could.  

As the years went by it seemed that most of the original joy I had in teaching faded into vague hostility between many in the class and me.

I quit teaching when I felt I was no longer successfully sharing how much I loved the beauty of chemistry.

@Francis

In my 40s I realized I really like teaching. Earlier I never minded it, but I also had no real passion for it. I taught, I published, and I was OK, but in no way outstanding, at both.

As I reached middle age, and talked with my dying mother about the meaning of life (and the universe and everything), I had a moment of clarity: I hate writing and publishing all those ridiculous papers that make no difference to the world, at all. I love teaching! So I changed my "career" track from research and teaching to pure teaching, and I've never been as satisfied with my job as I am now.

(I also love how much spare time a teacher at university enjoys üòÜ)

@Andrzej @Francis

One of my regrets is that I never went to any professor's Office Hours.  We Engineering students seemed to think that that would be considered a sign of weakness.

Any comments on your experience in that area?
eg, Who comes in?  What are they looking for?
Are they just trying to game the system?  etc

@Al  in Pittsburgh

I have office hours once per week, so some 15 times per semester. On average, 13 of those times nobody comes to see me. Those who do come usually do so near the end of the semester, to make ridiculous requests, like: Professor! I haven't been to any of the classes but I'd like to get credit for the course!

ü§∑

I always tell my students they are welcome to come and talk with me about anything course-related but they never seem to bother. Truth be told, I was just like them as a student, too.

@Al  in Pittsburgh

For my part, which ended in 2000, I think I saw every possibility.  Some might have been hoping to rise out of the crowd, as one of my classes sometimes had as many as 150 students.

Most came in with a question about a homework or quiz problem, so they were looking for how to solve a problem, or how to understand something.

I think they might have also been trying to establish a human connection, and I fully endorsed that.  They'd tell me about their high school chemistry, what it was like growing up in rural Tennessee.  I'd spin them tales from my past.

I never really had office hours.  I told students I was on campus from at least 8 in the morning to 6 in the evening, and that they should just track me down whenever they could find me.

@Francis

That‚Äôs just plain lovely.

We also have deer in our backyard woods.
As I solved today, the babes born last month
made my puppies go ballistic.
It happens often.

But *twice* in the past decade, 
we‚Äôve looked out and seen a tiny head
or two, sitting just above the
Creeping Myrtle that covers the hill beyond our creek.

Somehow the doe lets her
new babes know to lie down and stay put
while she looks for food.

Eight hours! Those sweet little heads
stay, frozen, trying to be invisible,
waiting for their mamma to return.

No point to this rambling.
Just sitting with this feeling of focusing
on the gentle creatures on 
the other side of the glass.

@Jerry Agree re. AMSTEREO! I filled in fMSTEREO and thought, "that's an odd clue, spoken word stations are notoriously on AM".

But I'd wager the constructor wasn't thinking of that...

Still, great puzzle otherwise!
@Jerry agreed. As Tim said- while technically possible to broadcast AM in stereo since 1993, very few stations ever bothered to so not many manufacturers bothered.

@Andrzej
I applaud your fascination with the word, the concept of it, and the moments of wonder it evokes. The Greek writers of mythology were such deep thinkers, it's almost frightening to catch a glimpse into such men's imagination.

Having been around during the initial FM Radio days, NYC‚Äôs WNEW-FM (102.5) was among the first to broadcast in true stereo. They introduced simulcasts, prompting the use of headphones by we consumers, and the stereo receiver industry just took off after that.

@Jerry

I suspect that your love of ETHER has to do with its connection to ETHEReal, a lovely word with powerful resonance for something so "airy".

But perhaps it's also fascinating as the material stuff of the heavens, beyond the air of our atmosphere.  Posited by the ancient Greeks, and still believed in up through the 19th century, as the stuff which carried light waves.  (How can you have waves without a material that transmits them?)   It's only with the Michelson-Morley experiment of 1887 that the existence of ETHER was "disproved", and the heavens became a place of vacuous nothingness.

Yes, I prefer (a)ETHER, too.
The concepts of the force in Star Wars and of subspace in Star Trek have a hint of ether about them, don't they?

In all fairness, Evian now sells distilled water in big plastic bottles, just like Dasani, only charging more for the Evian logo on the label. It‚Äôs an atrocity the Paris of your 7th grade trip probably never saw coming. 

My favorite scene from Colette‚Äôs Claudine in Paris, one that begat my teenage affectation: Renaud takes Claudine to a restaurant after the opera. She‚Äôs never been out to eat, nor has she ever had alcohol before, but he doesn‚Äôt know that. She points to a waiter walking by with table wine, so he orders it for them. Very thirsty, she chugs it and, of course, immediately proceeds to get very, very tipsy. The dialogue goes like this:

- Claudine! ne seriez-vous pas un peu... gaie, par hasard? Vous buvez sec ce soir, est-ce que chez vous ?...
- ÔªøÔªøChez moi, je sable l'eau d'√âvian, r√©-ponds-je, aimable et rassurante.

"Claudine! Aren't you by chance a little... cheerful tonight? You're drinking like a fish tonight‚Äîdo you at home?" 
‚ÄúAt home, I celebrate with nothing but Evian water," I reply, friendly and reassuring.‚Äù

(Pardon the clumsy translation. Only the French original is available online.)

Grinnell College, 1965

April 21: Classics Professor John Crossett
delivers what he calls a ‚Äúnon-lecture‚Äù offering a
close reading of Petula Clark‚Äôs hit single
‚ÄúDowntown‚Äù in North Lounge.

N.B. North Lounge was the dance space in the student union. He used the juke box as a lectern.

@HeathieJ - My experience with that song was just as indelible, if a bit more mundane. It was on the radio constantly the first year I was out of college. I had moved to Pittsburgh with my new husband, after acquiring an MRS along with my BA. Our apartment was about 1/2 drive away from the Pittsburgh downtown where we both had new jobs, along a route that gave us sights of the city buildings as we drove  together. In my memory, Petulia Clark was belting that song on the car radio nearly every morning.

@Helen Wright
Thank you for recognizing that. The central to west Texas region is notoriously arid and dry river beds are scattered throughout the landscape. Even with the sophisticated warning systems, a flash flood of the Guadalupe happens so quickly, it's difficult to avoid the disastrous effects.
The dried-up streams that branch off of it will fill up and take everything out in its path. Then, just as quickly as it destroys, it stops, and the streams dry up again.
What happened to our French Broad River in Tn and NC is not as common as the flooding in Tx. That disaster was devastating, as well, just very low casualties.
Good on you!

@Helen Wright

I watched that too. It was just horrifying!!  And horrible to watch the stories and the numbers unfolding. So grateful for every single one who made it through for everyone who helped!

@Matt Heffernan not true. AM Stereo did exist, if only ever so briefly. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AM_stereo

@Brux sure it *technically* existed, which is why it came up in the word-bank used by the puzzle generator or whatever, but the real issue is that it's just casually dropped in the puzzle as if it's a perfectly normal term, when in fact very few people know about this weird stereo AM technology (and even more confusingly, it's a complete oxymoron in the context of the AM/FM radio that most people are familiar with), so it ends up feeling like just plain ignorance on the part of the puzzle author.
